Cheers Jim, thanks for that. What is the Knutsen book on Polearms ?, can 
I=
 assume it is in english ?.

Best wishes

Rich

Jim Gilbert wrote:

> Rich,=

> =E7=AD=91=E7=B4=AB is read both chikushi and tsukushi.  The chiku kanji =
is an old 
> musical instrument and the shi kanji is the color purple (mura=
saki).  
> Together the kanji are an old name of Chikuzen and Chikugo and/o=
r of 
> all of Kyushu.  Papinot lists a daimyo family name using these 
> c=
haracters and says that they were taken from the village of 
> Chikuzen.  T=
he name of the naginata presumably refers to the place of 
> origin.  This =
would have been a point of contact with China in early 
> times. 
>
> Knuts=
en illustrates a few examples of these in his book on polearms.  
> He says=
 that they were used from the late Heian through late 
> Muromachi.  He rea=
ds it tsukushi.  Kajihara reads it chikushi in his 
> Glossary and illustra=
tes hirazukuri and unokubigata variations.
>
> Jim
>
>
>
>
>   Hi Jim, can =
you define Chikushi please ?.
>
>   Rich
>
>   Jim Gilbert wrote:
>
>   > I=
t's a chikushi naginata (=E7=AD=91=E7=B4=AB=E8=96=99=E5=88=80).
>   >
>   >=
 Jim
